SEARCH
Package com.icx.domain.sql

Class SqlDomainController

java.lang.Object
com.icx.common.Common
com.icx.domain.DomainController<SqlDomainObject>
com.icx.domain.sql.SqlDomainController
public class SqlDomainController extends DomainController<SqlDomainObject>
Domain controller for SQL based persistence mechanism. Provides methods to load and store domain objects from and to database. Provides also method to delete persisted objects from object store and database.

  • Nested Class Summary

    • registerStringConvertersForType

      public static void registerStringConvertersForType(Class<?> cls, Function<Object,String> toStringConverter, Function<String,Object> fromStringConverter)
      Register to-string and from-string converter for individual field types.

      Fields of types, for which to-string and from-string converters are defined, must be annotated by Annotations.StoreAsString annotation. Columns associated with these fields are of database specific string type - (N)VARCHAR(charsize). Values will be converted to string using to-string converter before being stored in database on save() and loaded values will be re-converted using from-string converter on loading objects from database (synchronize(), load...()).

      Registering specific to-string and from-string converters is effective only for value types which are not natively supported by Domain persistence mechanism (see Java2Sql).

      Note: Another possibility to define to-string and from-string conversion is to declare public methods toString() and valueOf(String) for specific field types, which than automatically will be called by Reflection for conversion on storing and retrieving field values. Registration of these methods is not necessary. Fields holding values of such types must also be annotated by Annotations.StoreAsString annotation.

      Parameters:
      cls - class of values to convert
      toStringConverter - to-string converter or null for toString()
      fromStringConverter - from-string converter

    • initialize

      public void initialize(Properties dbProperties, Properties domainProperties, String domainPackageName) throws DomainException, SQLException, ConfigException, SqlDbException
      Register domain classes by given domain package where these classes reside.

      All classes in this package and in any sub package which extend SqlDomainObject class will be registered as domain classes.

      Parameters:
      dbProperties - database connection properties ('dbConnectionString', 'dbUser', 'dbPassword')
      domainProperties - only 'dataHorizonPeriod' is relevant here (e.g. '1h', '30d')
      domainPackageName - name of package where domain classes reside
      Throws:
      DomainException - on error registering domain classes
      ConfigException - on invalid or missing database connection string or unsupported database type
      SQLException - if database connection cannot be established or on SQL errors associating domain classes and database tables
      SqlDbException - on errors associating domain classes and database tables

    • initialize

      @SafeVarargs public final void initialize(Properties dbProperties, Properties domainProperties, Class<? extends SqlDomainObject>... objectDomainClasses) throws DomainException, SQLException, ConfigException, SqlDbException
      Register given object domain classes and base domain classes.

      Provided classes must extend SqlDomainObject class. Only object domain class (highest class in inheritance order) must be provided here if inherited domain classes exists.

      Inner domain classes and parent domain classes (which are referenced by provided domain classes) will also be registered.

      Parameters:
      dbProperties - database connection properties ('dbConnectionString', 'dbUser', 'dbPassword')
      domainProperties - currently only 'dataHorizonPeriod' (e.g. '1h', '30d')
      objectDomainClasses - list of object domain classes to register
      Throws:
      DomainException - on error registering domain classes
      ConfigException - on invalid or missing database connection string of unsupported database type
      SQLException - if database connection cannot be established or on SQL errors associating domain classes and database tables
      SqlDbException - on errors associating domain classes and database tables

    • allValid

      public final <S extends SqlDomainObject> Set<S> allValid(Class<S> domainClass)
      Retrieve all registered and valid objects of a specific domain class.

      'valid' object means that object could be saved to database before without error (save(Connection, SqlDomainObject)).

      Type Parameters:
      S - specific domain object class type
      Parameters:
      domainClass - any domain class (must not be top-level/instantiable)
      Returns:
      set of all objects of given domain class

    • synchronize

      @SafeVarargs public final boolean synchronize(Class<? extends SqlDomainObject>... objectDomainClassesToExclude) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Synchronize domain objects controlled by this domain controller instance with the associated persistence database.

      Method first saves potentially existing new objects (objects which are not already stored in database) to database, than loads all currently relevant objects from database and after that unregisters objects which were deleted in database (by another instance) or which fell out of data horizon (Annotations.UseDataHorizon) and are not referenced by any loaded child object.

      Field values of existing local objects will be overridden by values retrieved from database on load. So, unsaved changes of field values, which were changed in database too, will be discarded and overridden by database values! Warn logs will be written and warnings will be assigned to affected objects in this case. It's recommended to ensure that all local changes are saved before calling synchronize().

      For data horizon controlled domain classes this method first loads only objects within data horizon (see Annotations.UseDataHorizon). But method ensures referential integrity by generally loading all referenced objects even if they are out of data horizon.

      This method is used for initial loading of domain objects from persistence database on startup. If there is a single domain controller instance connected to persistence database this method only removes objects which fell out of data horizon from object store on subsequent calls. This also means that for single domain controller instance configurations where data horizon control is not active it is sufficient to call this method once at startup.

      Parameters:
      objectDomainClassesToExclude - (optional) object domain classes which objects shall not be loaded from database - if objects of this classes are referenced by loaded objects they will be loaded anyway (referential integrity)
      Returns:
      true if at least one new or changed object was loaded from database, false otherwise
      Throws:
      SQLException - if executed SELECT statement throws SQLException
      SqlDbException - on Java/SQL inconsistencies

    • loadOnly

      public Set<SqlDomainObject> loadOnly(Class<? extends SqlDomainObject> objectDomainClass, String whereClause, int maxCount) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Load objects of only one (primary) object domain class (selected by WHERE clause if specified) and also objects directly or indirectly referenced by these primarily loaded objects (to ensure referential integrity).

      Note: To provide a WHERE clause one needs knowledge of the relation of Java class/field names and associated SQL table/column names and also knowledge about column types associated to field types:

      The basic rule for conversion of Java class/field names to SQL table/column names is: CaseFormat.UPPER_CAMEL -> CaseFormat.UPPER_UNDERSCORE. Tables are additionally prefixed by 'DOM_'. E.g.: class name -> table name: Xyz -> 'DOM_Xyz', XYZ -> 'DOM_X_Y_Z' and field name -> column name: xyz -> 'XYZ'. xYz -> 'X_YZ'.

      If field is a reference field referencing another domain class, the corresponding column has appendix '_ID' (object references are realized as foreign key columns referencing unique object id). E.g. class Bike { Manufacturer manufacturer; } -> column 'MANUFACTURER_ID' in table 'DOM_BIKE'.

      If field name is or may be a reserved name in SQL, column name is prefixed by 'DOM_' (e.g.: LocalDate date -> 'DOM_DATE', Type type -> 'DOM_TYPE', Double number -> 'DOM_NUMBER').

      Fixed values of String and Enum fields in WHERE clause have to be specified as string literals -> NAME='Order1' AND STATUS='open'. Number values (Integer, Long, Double, BigInteger, BigDecimal) have to be specified as appropriate numbers -> PRICE>12.0. LocalDate, LocalTime, LocalDateTime values have to be valid database specific date/time strings.

      Note: Columns for byte[], char[] and other array fields, as well as collection and map fields may not be used for WHERE clauses.

      Parameters:
      objectDomainClass - object domain class of primary objects to load
      whereClause - to further shrink amount of loaded objects
      maxCount - maximum number of primary objects to load
      Returns:
      objects loaded from database potentially including referenced objects of other classes than the given object domain class (referential integrity)
      Throws:
      SQLException - on opening database connection or performing SELECT statements
      SqlDbException - if object domain class of any referenced object could not be determined

    • reload

      public <S extends SqlDomainObject> boolean reload(S obj) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      (Re)load object from database.

      If object is not initially saved or is not registered, this method does nothing.

      If direct or indirect parent objects exist, which are not yet loaded due to data horizon condition, these object will be loaded (and instantiated) too.

      Attention: Overrides unsaved changes of this object.

      Type Parameters:
      S - specific domain object class type
      Parameters:
      obj - object to reload from database
      Returns:
      true, if object differs in and therefore was loaded from database, false otherwise
      Throws:
      SQLException - on error establishing database connection
      SqlDbException - if object domain class of any referenced object could not be determined

    • allocateObjectsExclusively

      public <S extends SqlDomainObject> Set<S> allocateObjectsExclusively(Class<S> objectDomainClass, Class<? extends SqlDomainObject> inProgressClass, String whereClause, int maxCount, Consumer<? super S> update) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Select and allocate objects of given domain class for exclusive use.

      This method is intended to synchronize access if multiple threads and/or multiple domain controller instances concurrently operate on the same database.

      Allocated objects must later be released from exclusive use using releaseObjects(Collection, Class).

      Note: exclusive allocation of objects is realized by inserting a record in a 'shadow' table for every allocated object with the object id as record id. The UNIQUE constraint for ID ensures, that this can be done only once for one object (No FOR UPDATE clause is used on SELECT statement for access synchronization).

      If 'update' function is specified this function will be computed initially for all exclusively allocated objects, and allocated objects will be saved to database immediately (e.g. o -> o.status = 'processing' -> STATUS = 'processing').

      Objects allocated here are typically already loaded by preceding synchronization.

      Type Parameters:
      S - specific domain object class type
      Parameters:
      objectDomainClass - object domain class of objects to allocate exclusively (non-object domain classes are not allowed here! E.g. if RaceBike extends Bike only RaceBike may be provided)
      inProgressClass - class for shadow records to ensure exclusivity of this operation - e.g. an inner class of given object domain class (or one of it's base classes) named InProgress extending SqlDomainObject
      whereClause - WHERE clause to build SELECT statement for objects to allocate (e.g. STATUS='new') - @see loadOnly(Class, String, int) for details regarding WHERE clause
      maxCount - maximum # of objects to allocate
      update - optional function to compute immediately on allocated objects (or null)
      Returns:
      allocated objects
      Throws:
      SQLException - exceptions thrown establishing connection or on executing SQL SELECT or UPDATE statement
      SqlDbException - on internal errors

    • allocateObjectExclusively

      public <S extends SqlDomainObject> boolean allocateObjectExclusively(S obj, Class<? extends SqlDomainObject> inProgressClass, Consumer<? super S> update) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Select and allocate one object for exclusive use.

      For exclusive object allocation see @allocateObjectsExclusively(Class, Class, String, int, Consumer).

      Allocated object must later be released from exclusive use using releaseObject(SqlDomainObject, Class, Consumer).

      If 'update' function is specified this function will be computed initially for allocated object, and object will be saved to database immediately (e.g. o -> o.status = 'processing' -> STATUS = 'processing').

      Type Parameters:
      S - specific domain object class type
      Parameters:
      obj - object to allocate exclusively
      inProgressClass - class for shadow records to ensure exclusivity of this operation - e.g. an inner class of given object domain class (or one of it's base classes) named InProgress extending SqlDomainObject
      update - optional function to compute immediately on allocated objects (or null)
      Returns:
      true if this object could be allocated exclusively, false otherwise
      Throws:
      SQLException - exceptions thrown establishing connection or on executing SQL UPDATE statement on saving object
      SqlDbException - on internal errors

    • releaseObject

      public <S extends SqlDomainObject> boolean releaseObject(S obj, Class<? extends SqlDomainObject> inProgressClass, Consumer<? super S> update) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Release this object from exclusive use.

      if 'update' function is given this function will be computed for this exclusively allocated objects and this objects will be saved to database immediately (e.g. o -> o.status = 'done' -> STATUS = 'done').

      Type Parameters:
      S - specific domain object class type
      Parameters:
      obj - object to release from exclusive use
      inProgressClass - class for shadow records to ensure exclusivity of this operation - @see allocateObjectExclusively(SqlDomainObject, Class, Consumer)
      update - update function to perform on this object on releasing or null (e.g. o -> o.status = 'done')
      Returns:
      true if object was exclusively allocated before, false otherwise
      Throws:
      SQLException - exceptions thrown establishing connection or on executing SQL UPDATE statement on saving object
      SqlDbException - on internal errors

    • releaseObjects

      public <S extends SqlDomainObject> void releaseObjects(Collection<S> objects, Class<? extends SqlDomainObject> inProgressClass) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Release multiple exclusively allocated objects from exclusive use.
      Type Parameters:
      S - specific domain object class type
      Parameters:
      objects - objects to release from exclusive use
      inProgressClass - class for shadow records to ensure exclusivity of this operation - @see allocateObjectExclusively(SqlDomainObject, Class, Consumer)
      Throws:
      SQLException - exceptions thrown establishing connection or on executing SQL UPDATE statement on saving object
      SqlDbException - on internal errors

    • computeExclusivelyOnObjects

      public <S extends SqlDomainObject> Set<S> computeExclusivelyOnObjects(Class<S> objectDomainClass, Class<? extends SqlDomainObject> inProgressClass, String whereClause, Consumer<? super S> update) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Exclusively compute a function on objects of one domain class and save updated objects immediately.

      Works like allocateObjectsExclusively(Class, Class, String, int, Consumer) but releases objects immediately after computing update function. Explicitly releasing updated objects is not necessary.

      Type Parameters:
      S - specific domain object class type
      Parameters:
      objectDomainClass - object domain class of objects to allocate exclusively
      inProgressClass - class for shadow records to ensure exclusivity of this operation - @see allocateObjectExclusively(SqlDomainObject, Class, Consumer)
      whereClause - WHERE clause to build SELECT statement for objects to allocate (e.g. STATUS='new') - @see loadOnly(Class, String, int) for details regarding WHERE clause
      update - update function to compute immediately on selected objects (or null) - objects will be saved immediately after computing (e.g. o -> o.status = 'done' -> STATUS = 'done')
      Returns:
      objects for which update function were computed
      Throws:
      SQLException - exceptions thrown establishing connection or on executing SQL SELECT or UPDATE statement
      SqlDbException - on internal errors

    • save

      public boolean save(Connection cn, SqlDomainObject obj) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Save object to database on existing database connection.

      If object is 'new', which means it was not stored in database before, appropriate INSERT statement(s) will be performed, otherwise UPDATE statements for changed fields. If there are no differences between object and object representation in database, nothing will be done and false will be returned.

      If (any) domain class of this object has array, collection or map fields, INSERT and UPDATE statements will also be performed on 'entry' tables associated with these fields.

      On saving an object one assumes that this object was not meanwhile changed in database (by another controller instance). If in doubt allocate object before saving using allocateObjectExclusively(SqlDomainObject, Class, Consumer) which reloads object from database and allows secure saving. Values of simple data and reference fields override values in database without any check on saving. For lists, set and array and map fields new value will be checked against value stored in local object record before removing, inserting or updating database entries which represent these complex fields. This may lead to unpredictable results on saving complex fields if they were changed and saved by another instance before!

      On SQL exception this exception and the field error(s) recognized will be assigned to the object. In this case object is marked as invalid and will not be found using allValid(Class). If object was already saved, UPDATE's will afterwards be tried for every field/column separately to keep impact of failure small. For non-updatable fields original content is restored to ensure data consistency between object and database representation.

      If a temporary invalid object can successfully be saved again (with changed and valid field values), assigned exception and field error(s) will be removed from object, so object than is considered again as valid. again.

      If initial saving - inserting object record(s) - fails, whole transaction will be rolled back (if connection is not in auto-commit mode).

      Parameters:
      cn - database connection
      obj - object to save
      Returns:
      true if object's changes were saved to database, false if object was up-to-date
      Throws:
      SQLException - exception thrown during execution of INSERT or UPDATE statement
      SqlDbException - on internal errors

    • save

      public boolean save(SqlDomainObject obj) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Save changed object to database.

      Grabs a non-auto-commit database connection form ConnectionPool assigned to this domain controller and gives this connection back after saving object.

      For detailed description see save(Connection, SqlDomainObject).

      Parameters:
      obj - object to save
      Returns:
      true if object's changes were saved to database, false if object was up-to-date
      Throws:
      SQLException - exception thrown during establishing database connection or execution of INSERT or UPDATE statement
      SqlDbException - on internal errors

    • createAndSave

      public <S extends SqlDomainObject> S createAndSave(Connection cn, Class<S> objectDomainClass, Consumer<S> init) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Create, initialize, register and save(Connection, SqlDomainObject) object of domain class using given database connection.

      If provided, calls initialization function before object registration to ensure that registered object is logically initialized.

      Note: method uses default constructor, which therefore must explicitly be defined if other constructors are defined!

      If object cannot be saved due to SQL exception on INSERT, object will marked as invalid and exception and field error(s) will be assigned to object.

      Type Parameters:
      S - specific domain object class type
      Parameters:
      cn - database connection
      objectDomainClass - top-level domain class of object to create (object domain class)
      init - object initialization function
      Returns:
      newly created domain object
      Throws:
      SqlDbException - on Java/SQL inconsistencies
      SQLException - on error saving object to database

    • createAndSave

      public <S extends SqlDomainObject> S createAndSave(Class<S> objectDomainClass, Consumer<S> init) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Create, initialize, register and save object of domain class.

      See createAndSave(Connection, Class, Consumer) and save(SqlDomainObject).

      Type Parameters:
      S - specific domain object class type
      Parameters:
      objectDomainClass - top-level domain class of objects to create (object domain class)
      init - object initialization function
      Returns:
      newly created and saved domain object
      Throws:
      SqlDbException - on Java/SQL inconsistencies
      SQLException - on error saving object to database

    • createAndSaveNoException

      public <S extends SqlDomainObject> S createAndSaveNoException(Class<S> objectDomainClass, Consumer<S> init)
      Create, initialize, register and save object of domain class without throwing exception on error.

      See createAndSave(Connection, Class, Consumer) and save(SqlDomainObject).

      On unsuccessful saving object will be marked as invalid and field error(s) will be assigned to object. Thrown exception will be logged as well as exception context.

      Type Parameters:
      S - specific domain object class type
      Parameters:
      objectDomainClass - top-level domain class of objects to create (object domain class)
      init - object initialization function
      Returns:
      newly created and saved domain object or null if an exception occurred saving object

    • delete

      public boolean delete(Connection cn, SqlDomainObject obj) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      If possible delete this object and all referencing objects using existing database connection.

      Deletion of an object means: unregistering object and all direct and indirect child objects from object store, deleting associated records from database tables and removing object from potentially existing accumulations of parent objects.

      Initially checks if this object and all of the direct and indirect children can be deleted (see DomainObject.canBeDeleted()). No object will be deleted at all if this check fails (and connection is non-auto-commit).

      Note: Database records of old 'data horizon' controlled child objects (which are not registered), will be deleted directly by ON DELETE CASCADE clause (which is automatically defined for FOREIGN KEYs in tables of 'data horizon' controlled domain classes in SQL scripts for database generation).

      Parameters:
      cn - database connection
      obj - object to delete
      Returns:
      true if deletion was successful, false if object or at least one of its direct or indirect children cannot be deleted by can-be-deleted check.
      Throws:
      SQLException - exceptions thrown on executing SQL DELETE statement
      SqlDbException - on internal errors

    • delete

      public boolean delete(SqlDomainObject obj) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      If possible delete object and all referencing objects .

      Grabs a non-auto-commit database connection form connection pool (ConnectionPool assigned to database connection object SqlDb and gives this connection back after deletion.

      See delete(Connection, SqlDomainObject).

      Parameters:
      obj - object to delete
      Returns:
      true if deletion was successful, false if object or at least one of its direct or indirect children cannot be deleted by can-be-deleted check.
      Throws:
      SQLException - exceptions thrown establishing connection or on executing SQL DELETE statement
      SqlDbException - on internal errors

    • hasConstraintViolations

      public boolean hasConstraintViolations(SqlDomainObject obj)
      Check for constraint violations of a domain object without involving database.

      Logs violations found and assigns field errors on fields for which constraints are violated.

      Note: column size violation are detected here only for enum fields - values of String fields which are to long for corresponding column will be truncated and a field warning will be generated on saving.

      Parameters:
      obj - object to check
      Returns:
      true if any field constraint is violated, false otherwise
